title: Your Complete Guide to Turning a Wireless Headset Into a Wired One

steps.title: Buy a DC-DC step-up step-down module.
steps.content: Buy a DC-DC step-up step-down module. You can find them cheaply online. You'll need a few more tools, too, listed below.

steps.title: Cut the USB cable about 6" - 10" from the end that plugs into your PC or console.
steps.content: Cut the USB cable about 6" - 10" from the end that plugs into your PC or console. This is where we'll connect the step-up step-down module.

steps.title: Use the utility knife to slice the insulation of the USB cable about an inch down from where you cut it, on both sides.
steps.content: Use the utility knife to slice the insulation of the USB cable about an inch down from where you cut it, on both sides. Pull out the tiny wires inside.

steps.title: Cut away the other wires and excess insulation.
steps.content: Cut away the other wires and excess insulation. We only need the red and black wires in the cable.

steps.title: Use your wire cutters to strip about half of each exposed wire.
steps.content: Use your wire cutters to strip about half of each exposed wire. Be careful not to use too much pressure. The wires are very small; too much pressure and you'll cut the wire instead of stripping it.

steps.title: Twist the bare-stranded copper and insert them into the module.
steps.content: Twist the bare-stranded copper and insert them into the module. The end that goes into the PC/console gets screwed to the "IN" terminals, and the other end for the headset gets screwed to the "OUT" terminals. Red wire is for the positive, and black wire is for the negative.

steps.title: Adjust the voltage output of the module.
steps.content: Adjust the voltage output of the module. To do this, plug the USB cable into your PC or console. You'll be using the USB ports on the PC or gaming console as your power source, but you could even plug it into a phone charger and use that as your power source. This particular module can take any input of 3.5-28V and give an output of 1.25V-26V. Once it's plugged in, you'll need to use your 1.4mm screwdriver to adjust the small screw on the module. Using your multimeter to read the voltage, turn the screw until the output of the module reads 3V.

steps.title: Cut the other end of the USB cable off (the end that would plug into a phone or something).
steps.content: Cut the other end of the USB cable off (the end that would plug into a phone or something).

steps.title: Use the utility knife and slice the insulation about 3" - 4" down from the cut.
steps.content: Use the utility knife and slice the insulation about 3" - 4" down from the cut. Pull out the wires.

steps.title: Cut away the excess wires and insulation.
steps.content: Cut away the excess wires and insulation. Strip the ends of the red and black wires. Set the cable aside for now.

steps.title: Remove the ear pad from the side the batteries insert into.
steps.content: Remove the ear pad from the side the batteries insert into.

steps.title: Use a small screwdriver (or T6 Torx if you're working on the X42) to remove the screws and reveal the wires insides.
steps.content: Use a small screwdriver (or T6 Torx if you're working on the X42) to remove the screws and reveal the wires insides. Be careful of the part with the speaker in it. It is only connected by two small wires that could pull out of their soldered joint.

steps.title: Take off the battery cover and insert the end of the USB cable through the opening by the spring.
steps.content: Take off the battery cover and insert the end of the USB cable through the opening by the spring. Alternatively, you can drill a hole through the side to insert the cable through. Use a bit slightly larger than your USB cable. Use silicone or, more preferably, a hot glue gun to keep the wire in place.

steps.title: Using the soldering iron, solder the red wire to the positive terminal.
steps.content: Using the soldering iron, solder the red wire to the positive terminal. There should be a speaker wire connected here.

steps.title: Solder the black wire to the negative terminal (the one with spring on the other side).
steps.content: Solder the black wire to the negative terminal (the one with spring on the other side). Make sure you solder it to the one with speaker wire as well. Keep in mind you aren't soldering these wires to either of the terminals that have the red wire connecting the positive and negative terminals.

steps.title: Close it back up and put the ear pad back on.
steps.content: Close it back up and put the ear pad back on. You've just turned your wireless headset into a wired headset! Just remember we aren't replacing any receiver, just the batteries, so don't throw it out!
